it goes on bout its day so it's very fast very atomic very quick right but one of the challenges with a block based
file system is that they don't scale after you get to a certain point you know in the you know multiple terabytes down they have gotten better but they
still don't scale you start running into issues like let's say for example I wanted to write a billion one kilobyte
files to a block-based filesystem anybody here think I could actually make that happen with a default formatted
file system no right come and run out of inode I'm gonna have file allocation
table problems I'm gonna have all kinds of i/o issues so when you start talking
about scaling huge amounts of files and you want to make them available to very large numbers of people you have to
decouple the storage and retrieval of the actual objects from the metadata itself and so this is where object
storage comes into play right so the idea is instead of when I change this one letter on this document what I'm
going to do is I'm actually going to save the entire document over again it's a different version because all I'm doing is just storing blobs of
information and then what I do in my metadata service is I change the pointer that says this is the new version of
that object so it's really fast because I've decoupled those two operations from one another so in in s3 which is our simple storage
